column1: 259.0|Why polar bears are not found in southern hemisphere?|You are a helpful assistant|Polar bears (Ursus maritimus) are native to the Arctic region
column2: which is located in the Northern Hemisphere. There are several reasons why polar bears are not found in the Southern Hemisphere:

column1: 1. **Habitat Requirements**: Polar bears are adapted to live in cold
column3: primarily on sea ice in the Arctic Ocean and its surrounding seas and coastlines. The Southern Hemisphere does not have the same type of sea ice habitat that polar bears depend on for hunting seals

column1: 2. **Geographic Distribution**: The distribution of polar bears is closely linked to the Arctic ice caps. The Antarctic region
column3: is very different from the Arctic. Instead of a polar bear habitat
column4: the Antarctic is home to seals
column6: and other species that are adapted to its specific environment.

column1: 3. **Evolutionary History**: Polar bears evolved from brown bears and adapted to life in the Arctic over thousands of years. Their evolution was shaped by the specific conditions of the Northern Hemisphere
column2: leading to their current adaptations for survival in extremely cold conditions and reliance on sea ice.

column1: 4. **Ecological Niches**: Different species have evolved to fill ecological niches in various regions around the world. In the Southern Hemisphere
column2: large carnivores adapted to cold climates include species like the leopard seal
column3: which occupies a niche similar to that of the polar bear in the Antarctic ecosystem.

column4: and ecological adaptation explains why polar bears are exclusively found in the Northern Hemisphere and not in the Southern Hemisphere.|2025/03/04 12:58:42.661401000
